text: I hear they might promote Bryukhanov.
speaker: FOMIN

text: This little problem we have with the safety test...
speaker: FOMIN

text: if it's completed successfully,
speaker: FOMIN

text: yes, I think promotion's very likely.
speaker: FOMIN

text: Who knows, maybe Moscow.
speaker: FOMIN

text: Naturally, they'll put me in charge once he's gone,
speaker: FOMIN

text: and then I'll need someone to take my old job.
speaker: FOMIN

text: I could pick Sitnikov.
speaker: FOMIN

text: I would like to be considered.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: I'll keep that in mind.
speaker: FOMIN

text: Viktor Petrovich,
speaker: FOMIN

text: preparations for the test have gone smoothly.
speaker: FOMIN

text: Comrade Dyatlov's been working per my instructions,
speaker: FOMIN

text: and Reactor 4 output's been reduced to 1600 megawatts.
speaker: FOMIN

text: With your approval, we're ready to continue lowering power to...
speaker: FOMIN

text: We have to wait.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Is, uh...?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Are you going to ask me if there's a problem, Nikolai?
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: You can't read a fucking face?
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Three years, I've tried to finish this test.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Three years.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: I've just had a call from the grid controller in Kiev.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: He says we can't lower power any further,
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: not for another ten hours.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: The grid controller? Where does he get off...
speaker: DYATLOV

text: It's not the grid controller's decision, Dyatlov.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: It's the end of the month.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: All the productivity quotas.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Everyone's working overtime, the factories need power.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Someone's pushing down from above.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Although, we'll never know who.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: So, do we have to scrap it or what?
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: No, I don't think so.
speaker: FOMIN

text: If we need to wait ten hours,
speaker: FOMIN

text: - we wait - Running at half power,
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: we're not going to have stability issues?
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: - No, I-I should think... - I'm not asking you.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: It's safe.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: We'll maintain at 1600.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: I'll go home, get some sleep, come back tonight.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: We'll proceed then.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: I'll personally supervise the test.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: And it will be completed.
speaker: DYATLOV

text: Well, I'm not waiting around then.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

text: Call me when it's done.
speaker: BRYUKHANOV

speaker: CHARKOV

text: How do you feel?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You went to the doctor yesterday.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: How is your health?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You don't know?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: From Vienna.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Do you read German?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It says, "At last a Soviet scientist who tells the truth."
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Obviously, I resent the insinuation,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: but I think it's fair to say,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: you made an excellent impression at the conference.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Turns out, you're quite good at this.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: At what? Lying?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Statecraft, Legasov. Statecraft.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The West is now satisfied
speaker: CHARKOV

text: that Chernobyl was solely the result of operator error,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: which it essentially was.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We have you to thank for that,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and we intend to.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: "Hero of the Soviet Union."
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Our highest honor.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They haven't even given it to me.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: "Promotion to Director of the Kurchatov Institute."
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm humbled.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I don't think there's anything humble about you, Valery Alexeyevich.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: These rewards are not yours yet.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: First, your testimony at the trial.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Charkov, I understand my duty to the State.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But you gave us assurances.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The reactors would be made safe.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It's been months, no changes have been made.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: changes even discussed. - First, the trial.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Once it's over, we will have our villains,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: we will have our hero, we will have our truth.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: After that, we can deal with the reactors.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Did you take a train?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yes, I took a train.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: Now let's talk about Vienna.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: I'm not here to scold you.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: I know how the world works despite what Shcherbina says.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: So... why are you here?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Because I'm brutally stubborn.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: Which you were hoping for.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: Charkov is saying they're going to fix the reactors after the trial.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Do you believe him?
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: The State will never willingly fix the reactors,
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: because acknowledging the problem means admitting that they lied.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: They will have to be forced.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: At the trial, you're going to tell the truth.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: You're going to convince the jury.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: It's a show trial.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The jury's already been handed their verdict.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm not talking about them.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: The Central Committee have invited
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: members of the scientific community to observe the trial.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: Our colleagues, from Kurchatov,
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: from Sredmash, from Minenergo,
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: they will be sitting in the crowd listening to every word you say.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: A jury that only we know is there.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: And when your testimony arrives at the moment of the explosion?
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: That is when our jury will finally hear the truth.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: And do what with it? - Insist on reform.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Not just to the RBMK, but the entire industry.
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: No, no, no, no, no.
speaker: SHCHERBINA

text: - They can't function without us. - No, no, no.
speaker: SHCHERBINA

text: Do you know what happened to Volkov
speaker: KHOMYUK

text: the man whose report you found?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They just removed him from his position at the Institute.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Sacked for the crime of knowing.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And you think that these scientists,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: handpicked to witness a show trial,
speaker: SHCHERBINA

text: will somehow be stirred into action by me?
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Because of some heroic stance I take in defiance of the State?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yes. - Why?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Because you're Valery Legasov, and you mean something.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'd like to think that if I spoke out, it would be enough.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But I know how the world works.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They will shoot me, Khomyuk.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You told me to find out what happened.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: I spoke to dozens of people.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Every word they said, I wrote down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: All in these books.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: These are the ones who are still alive.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: These are the ones who are dead.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They died rescuing each other.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Putting out fires, tending to the wounded.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They didn't hesitate, they didn't waiver.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They simply did what had to be done.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: So have I.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: So have I.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I went willingly to an open reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: So I've already given my life.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Isn't that enough?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No, I'm sorry, but it is not.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: has determined that justice be carried out
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: on behalf of the People
speaker: CHARKOV

text: in accordance with the general goal of our Party
speaker: LEGASOV

text: as determined by its 20th, 21st, and 22nd Congresses,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: which is a Leninist goal.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It was, is, and will be
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the only immutable goal in the Soviet state.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: The path of Leninist principles
speaker: CHARKOV

text: shall be consistently and undeviatingly followed
speaker: CHARKOV

text: as it expresses the vital interests of the Soviet People,
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: its hopes and aspirations
speaker: LEGASOV

text: as we guide the life of the Party and the State.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: This session of court is now open,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Judge Milan Kadnikov presiding.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Indictments:
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Viktor Bryukhanov,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Anatoly Dyatlov,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Nikolai Fomin...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: are accused of violating Article 220 Section 2
speaker: LEGASOV

text: of the Criminal Code of the Soviet Union,
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: resulting in a nuclear disaster on April 26, 1986.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The State calls witnesses Comrade Khomyuk
speaker: CHARKOV

text: of the Byelorussian Nuclear Institute,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Legasov of the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and Comrade Boris Evdokimovich Shcherbina,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and head of the Bureau for Fuel and Energy.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It began with, of all things, a safety test.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Why was there need for a safety test at all?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Reactor Number 4 was not new when the accident occurred.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In fact, it went into operation on December 20th, 1983.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Eleven days later, on the last day of the year,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Plant Director Viktor Bryukhanov signed this document...
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: certifying the completion of the construction of the reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As a result of finishing the work before the end of the year,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Bryukhanov was awarded Hero of Socialist Labor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Fomin was awarded for Valorous Labor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Dyatlov was given an Order of the Red Banner.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But their work was not finished.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And this document was a lie.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In order to sign this certificate,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: all safety tests had to have been successfully completed,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and yet, one remained.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: A nuclear reactor generates heat in the core here.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: A series of pumps, here and here,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: send a constant flow of cooling water through the core.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The core's heat turns the water to steam,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and the steam spins the turbine here,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and the result is electricity.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But what if a power plant has no power?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: What if the power feeding the plant itself is disrupted?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: A blackout, equipment failure,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: or an attack by a foreign enemy?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: If there's no power,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the pumps cannot move water through the core.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And without water, the core overheats,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the fuel melts down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In short, a nuclear disaster.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The solution?
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Three diesel fuel backup generators here.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: So, problem solved?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: No.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Bryukhanov knew that the problem was not solved at all.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The backup generators took approximately one minute
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to reach the speed required
speaker: LEGASOV

text: to power the pumps and prevent a meltdown,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and by that time, it would be too late.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: So we arrive at the safety test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The theory was this: If the facility lost power,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the turbine, which had been spinning,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: would take some time to slow down and stop.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What if you could take the electricity
speaker: CHARKOV

text: it was still generating and transfer it to the pumps?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What if the dying turbine
speaker: LEGASOV

text: could keep the pumps working long enough
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to bridge the 60-second gap until the generators came on?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Any questions?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No. Continue, please.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: To test this theory,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the reactor is placed in a reduced power mode...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 700 megawatts...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: to simulate a blackout condition.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Then the turbines are turned off,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and as they slowly spin down,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: their electrical output is measured
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to see if it's enough to power the pumps.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The science is strong,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but a test is only as good as the men carrying it out.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Now, the first time they tried, they failed.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The second time they tried, they failed.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: The third time they tried, they failed.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The fourth time they tried
speaker: LEGASOV

text: was April 26th, 1986.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Khomyuk.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: To understand what happened that night,
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: we have to go back ten hours earlier...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: April 25th, the day the test was meant to take place.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: By two in the afternoon,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the reactor has been lowered by half
speaker: LEGASOV

text: from its normal output level of 3200 megawatts
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to 1600 megawatts and is stable
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and ready to be reduced to its final output level for the test:
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 700 megawatts.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But before they can proceed, there is a phone call.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Power grid officials in Kiev say that they cannot afford
speaker: CHARKOV

text: a further reduction in the electricity until after midnight.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They are asking for a ten-hour delay.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: This is the first critical moment,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the first link in the chain of disaster.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Competent management would have insisted on canceling the test.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: These three men allowed it to proceed.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Why was this delay so dangerous?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It created two problems:
speaker: CHARKOV

text: One of them is scientific in nature...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and the other is very human.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: This is the one we will consider first.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: At midnight, there is a shift change.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Hey.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Khodemchuk... - Forget it. Find another fool.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Toptunov, want to buy a motorcycle?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Toptunov? He's just a little boy.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: He's got more hair on his face than on his balls.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Hair? Is that what's on his lip?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Leonid Fedorovych.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Akimov says to come to the control room as soon as you can.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Is he already here? - he came in early.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Something about a test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You see? Desperate.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Sasha?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Ah. You know the test they were supposed to run?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The turbine rundown, they tried it last year.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They couldn't do it on the day shift, so they've given it to us.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: To us?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - We don't know what... - Shh.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - We don't know what it is. - It's fine.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We take it down to 700, hold it there,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the rest is Stolyarchuk and Kirschenbaum, but...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Dyatlov is gonna be supervising.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I have to do something I've never done before
speaker: LEGASOV

text: with Dyatlov looking over my shoulder?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yeah, well, don't worry, we'll do it together.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm looking at the instructions now.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Are we supposed to do those or not?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yes, this is Akimov in 4.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I have the manual for the rundown test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You did it last year.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yes, in the program there's instructions of what to do,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and then, well, there's a lot of things crossed out.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What should I...?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Well, what should I...?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Are you sure?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Right. Thank you.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: He says to follow the crossed-out instructions.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: So then why are they crossed out?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We've been cleared to run the test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 1600. Good.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Now, is it too much to ask that you all know what you're doing?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Well... - Yes. Absolutely.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Stolyarchuk? - Yes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - Kirschenbaum? - Uh, I haven't reviewed.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We only just found out really...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There, review it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Or you can just do what I tell you.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I think even you, stupid as you are, can manage that.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Well, let's go.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I'm supposed to switch the turbine off while the reactor's still running?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - This is not good... - Shut the fuck up and do your job!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Toptunov, reduce power to 700.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I've never done this with the power so low before.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It's okay. I'm with you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Reducing power to 700.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I want you to think of Yuri Gagarin.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I want you to imagine that he has been told nothing
speaker: LEGASOV

text: of his mission into space until the moment that he is on the launch pad.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I want you to imagine that all he has
speaker: CHARKOV

text: is a list of instructions that he has never seen before,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: some of which have been crossed out.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: This is exactly what was happening
speaker: LEGASOV

text: in the control room of Reactor 4.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The night shift had not been trained to perform the experiment.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They hadn't even been warned it was happening.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Leonid Toptunov,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the operator responsible for controlling and stabilizing
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: the reactor that night was... all of 25 years old.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And his total experience on the job?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Four months.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: This is the human problem created by the delay.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But inside the reactor core,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: in the space between the atoms themselves,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: something far more dangerous is forming.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: A poison.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The time is 28 past midnight.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Legasov.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm pleased to see some of my colleagues here
speaker: CHARKOV

text: from the Kurchatov Institute and Minenergo.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But you don't need to be a nuclear scientist
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to understand what happened at Chernobyl.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: You only need to know this:
speaker: CHARKOV

text: there are essentially two things that happen
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: inside a nuclear reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The reactivity which generates power
speaker: LEGASOV

text: either goes up, or it goes down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: That's it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: All the operators do is maintain balance.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Uranium fuel.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As uranium atoms split apart and collide,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: reactivity goes up.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But if you don't balance the reactivity,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: it never stops rising. So...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Boron control rods.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They reduce reactivity like brakes on a car.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But there's a third factor to consider: water.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Cool water takes heat out of the system.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As it does, it turns to steam, or what we call a "void."
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: In an RBMK reactor of the type used at Chernobyl,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: there's something called a "positive void coefficient."
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What does that mean?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It means that the more steam present within the system,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the higher the reactivity,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: which means more heat, which means more steam,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: which means...
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: It would appear we have a vicious cycle on our hands.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And we would, were it not for this...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And we would, were it not for this:
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the negative temperature coefficient.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: When nuclear fuel gets hotter, it gets less reactive, so...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: fuel increases reactivity.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Control rods and water reduce it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Steam increases it,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and the rise in temperature reduces it.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: This is the invisible dance
speaker: LEGASOV

text: that powers entire cities without smoke or flame.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And it is beautiful
speaker: LEGASOV

text: when things are normal.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As uranium splits apart to release energy,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: it breaks down into a new element, xenon.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Xenon reduces reactivity.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: This is the poison Comrade Khomyuk mentioned.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: When the core is running at full power,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: it burns the xenon away before it can cause a problem.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But because of the delay,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Chernobyl Reactor 4 has been held at half power
speaker: CHARKOV

text: for ten hours.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The xenon did not burn away.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It built up, poisoning the core.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We're starting to lose balance.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: At 28 minutes past midnight,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the reactor is now primed to slow down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And yet, in less than an hour, it will explode.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: If you can't understand how a stalled nuclear reactor
speaker: LEGASOV

text: could lead to an explosion, I don't blame you.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: After all, you don't work in the control room
speaker: CHARKOV

text: of a nuclear power plant.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But as it turned out, the men who did
speaker: CHARKOV

text: didn't understand it either.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Easy now.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Take it down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Good. Like that.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You should have finished by now.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We're following protocol for reduction rate.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You're procrastinating.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There are ten other men in this plant who would've done it already.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Keep working. You're doing fine.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Kirschenbaum, come get me when these old women are ready.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yes, Comrade Dyatlov.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Okay, very slow now.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Let's ease it down to 700.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - Whoa, whoa, whoa. Slow. - I-I didn't move any rods there.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - What is this? - I'm not even touching it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We did everything right. I think that maybe the core is poisoned.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Well, if you thought the core was poisoned,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: then you didn't do everything right,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: because you're choking my reactor!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Get it back up!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Uh, I think if we turn off LAC,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: it may be possible to get more control.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: do it. Go. - Switch off local automatic control.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Go to global. Leonid.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: LAC disabled. Global control activated.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What did you do?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - I-I did what you said. I switched... - Look at it!
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - I don't understand. - Fucking amateurs.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You stalled the reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: How the fuck did you get this job?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Dyatlov...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You're gonna tell me you did everything right again,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: you incompetent asshole?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I apologize for this unsatisfactory result.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: what are you doing? - we have to Shut all the way down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: No. - we could be in a xenon pit.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We have to shut down and wait for 24 hours.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No. We're doing the test tonight. Raise power to 700.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We can't raise the power from here.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - The rules... - Don't talk to me about rules.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - If we fall from 80%... - No, no. We fell from 50%.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - Fifty percent is worse! - The rules don't say 50!
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - There is no rule! - Comrade Dyatlov,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I apologize, but what you're saying makes no sense.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Raise the power. - No.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I won't do it. It isn't safe.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Safety first. Always.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I've been saying that for 25 years.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: That's how long I've done this job, 25 years.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Is that longer than you, Akimov?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: #NAME?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And you with your mother's tit barely out of your mouth?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: So if I say it's safe, it's safe.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And if the two of you disagree,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: then you don't have to work here and you won't.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But not just here. You won't work at Kursk
speaker: LEGASOV

text: or Ignalina or Leningrad or Novo-Voronezh.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: You won't work anywhere ever again. I'll see to it.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I think you know I will see to it.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Raise the power.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I would like you to record your command.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Raise the power.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Together, then.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I wasn't even there.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I wasn't in the room when they raised the power.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: If you weren't there, then where were you?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Legasov, you are a witness, not a prosecutor.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I will ask the questions here.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: If you weren't in the room, then where were you?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The toilet.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The toilet?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Khomyuk interviewed everyone
speaker: CHARKOV

text: who was in the control room that night.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They all told the same story.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: "I knew what Dyatlov ordered was wrong,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but if I didn't do what he said, I would be fired."
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Leonid Toptunov.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: One day before he died.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: No, Comrade Dyatlov, you were in the room.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You ordered them to raise the power.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: This is a fact.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Court is now in recess.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Thirty minutes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Do you know anything about this town, Chernobyl?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Not really, no.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It was mostly Jews and Poles.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The Jews were killed in pogroms,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and Stalin forced the Poles out.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And then the Nazis came and killed whoever was left.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But after the war...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: people came to live here anyway.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They knew the ground under their feet was soaked in blood,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but they didn't care.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Dead Jews, dead Poles.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But not them.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: No one ever thinks it's going to happen to them.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: And here we are.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: How much time?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Maybe a year.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They call it a...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They call it a "long illness."
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It doesn't seem very long to me.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I know you told me, and I believed you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But time passed, and I thought,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: it wouldn't happen to me.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I wasted it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I wasted it all for nothing.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: For nothing?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Do you remember that morning when I first called you,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: how unconcerned I was?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I don't believe much that comes out of the Kremlin,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: but when they told me they were putting me
speaker: LEGASOV

text: in charge of the cleanup
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and they said it wasn't serious, I believed them.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You know why?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Because they put you in charge.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Yeah.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm an inconsequential man, Valera.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: That's all I've ever been.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I hoped that one day I would matter, but I didn't.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I just stood next to people who did.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There are other scientists like me.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Any one of them could have done what I did.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But you...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Everything we asked for, everything we needed.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Men, material, lunar rovers.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Who else could have done these things?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They heard me, but they listened to you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Of all the ministers and all the deputies...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: entire congregation of obedient fools...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: they mistakenly sent the one good man.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: For god's sake, Boris,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: you were the one who mattered most.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Ah, it's beautiful.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Legasov.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The time is 38 past midnight.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The reactor is nearly shut down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The operators of Reactor 4 are locked on a path
speaker: LEGASOV

text: that leads directly to disaster.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There's no way to turn back.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They do not yet know it, but the die is cast.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: At 30 megawatts, xenon is still being created,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but none of it is burning away.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The reactor is drowning in poison.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: To make matters worse, the reactor isn't hot enough
speaker: LEGASOV

text: to produce sufficient steam.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The only way to safely raise power from this state
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: is to do it very, very slowly
speaker: LEGASOV

text: over the course of 24 hours.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But Dyatlov wants it done now.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Akimov and Toptunov have only one course of action.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They begin pulling control rods out.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Dozens at a time.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Halfway out, three-quarters of the way out,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: still, the power does not budge.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: So they begin pulling them all the way out.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There were 211 control rods in Reactor 4.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Akimov and Toptunov completely withdrew 205.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Remember... control rods are the brakes on this car.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Of 211 rods, only six now remain in the reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As for the fuel, it's gone cold,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: so the negative temperature coefficient
speaker: LEGASOV

text: is no longer weighing down the reactivity.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But even still, the xenon poisoning is so strong,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the best they can do is raise the power to 200 megawatts.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: The control rods are out.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The emergency system has been disconnected.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The only thing keeping the reactor in check
speaker: LEGASOV

text: is water and xenon.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It's one in the morning. The test is minutes away.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I'm sorry, this is all we can get.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It's 200 megawatts. We've pulled almost everything out.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: If that's all we have, that's all we have.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - But the test requires 700. - Stolyarchuk, let's get ready.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: - Switch on pump 4. - No, wait a second.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Stolyarchuk... - we have barely enough steam as it is.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The turbine is going too slow for the test to deliver any valid results.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: - It's enough. - And if we add more water,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - there will be even less... - I said it's enough.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I know what I'm doing. Stolyarchuk.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Main Pump 4, connected.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We should warn Khodemchuk. The pipes are gonna be...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Never mind him. Kirschenbaum?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The steam in the separator drum is too low... five atmospheres.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: All right, let's all help him. Get it up as best you can.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We should stop.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Turn that fucking thing off.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You have 15 minutes.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Fifteen minutes.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: They may as well have had 15 days.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The problem they were facing was not solvable.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The power was too low, the water was too high.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The test was already ruined.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The results would have been useless,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but Dyatlov didn't care.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: All he wanted to do was report a completed test.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Less than two minutes remain.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yuvchenko, a mechanical engineer, is in his office.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Perevozchenko, reactor section foreman,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: is in the refueling hall,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: high above the 1,000-ton steel reactor cover.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Degtaryenko and Khodemchuk,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: circulation operators, are in the pump room.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: None of them have been told
speaker: CHARKOV

text: about the test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: None of them know what is about to happen.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: At 1:22 and 30 seconds,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Toptunov sees a report
speaker: LEGASOV

text: from the reactor's SKALA computer system.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Based on the absence of sufficient control rods,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the computer is recommending that the reactor be shut down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Well, of course it's saying that.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It doesn't know we're running a test.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: All right, comrades.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Another few minutes, it will all be over.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Kirschenbaum, when you're ready.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We did everything right.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Oscillograph on.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Closing Number 8 throttle valve.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Generator rotor beginning rundown.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 1:23 and four seconds.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: With every decision,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: they have pulled this reactor back like a slingshot,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: further than anyone has ever pulled,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: now the test begins.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The pumps are shut down, and they've let go.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The pumps stop moving water through the reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Uranium fuel is now unchecked by fresh coolant,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: unchecked by control rods.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The balance immediately swings in the opposite direction.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: In less than a second,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: reactivity increases.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Inside the core,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the remaining water is quickly converting to steam.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: A void is being created.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: There is no fresh water to replace it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Steam increases reactivity,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: increases heat, increases steam,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: increases reactivity.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The remaining xenon decays away.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The power is rising.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: There's nothing left to stop it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 1:23 and 35 seconds.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We have a power surge! Sasha!
speaker: CHARKOV

text: What did you do?!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 1:23 and 40 seconds.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In every control room of every nuclear reactor in the world,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: there is a button with one single purpose...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: to "scram," or instantly shut down, the reaction.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In Soviet reactors, that button is called AZ-5.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You press AZ-5, all of the control rods insert at once,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: and the reaction is stopped dead.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What are you waiting for, Legasov? Tell your lies.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Comrade Dyatlov, you will not be warned again.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - Or what? - For god's sake, Dyatlov.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Legasov's already given it away.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: He said before, there was no way to avoid what was coming.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: he knows something. She knows something. - Comrade Dyatlov.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: I know what you are, Valery Alexeyevich.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - You're a liar. - We've heard enough for today.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The defendants will be remanded in custody.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: - Court will... - I... I haven't finished.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I still have more evidence to give.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It's not necessary. Your testimony is concluded.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: your Honor. - Court Is now adjourned.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: we will resume tomorrow with... - Let him finish.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Shcherbina...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Let him finish.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Dyatlov broke every rule we have.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: He pushed a reactor to the brink of destruction.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: He did these things believing there was a failsafe.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: AZ-5, a simple button to shut it all down.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But in the circumstances he created, there wasn't.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The shutdown system had a fatal flaw.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: At 1:23:40, Akimov engages AZ-5.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The fully-withdrawn control rods
speaker: LEGASOV

text: begin moving back into the reactor.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: These rods are made of boron, which reduces reactivity,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but not their tips.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The tips are made of graphite, which accelerates reactivity.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Why?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Why?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: For the same reason our reactors
speaker: LEGASOV

text: do not have containment buildings around them,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: like those in the West.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: For the same reason we don't use
speaker: LEGASOV

text: properly enriched fuel in our cores.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: For the same reason we are the only nation
speaker: LEGASOV

text: that builds water-cooled, graphite-moderated reactors
speaker: LEGASOV

text: with a positive void coefficient.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It's cheaper.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The first part of the rods that enter the core
speaker: LEGASOV

text: are the graphite tips.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And when they do, the reaction in the core,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: which had been rising, skyrockets.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Every last molecule of liquid water
speaker: LEGASOV

text: instantly converts to steam,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: which expands and ruptures a series of fuel rod channels.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The control rods in those channels can move no further.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The graphite tips are fixed in position,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: endlessly accelerating the reaction.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Chernobyl Reactor 4 is now a nuclear bomb.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Perevozchenko looks down
speaker: CHARKOV

text: on the enormous steel lid of the reactor...
speaker: LEGASOV

text: ...and sees the impossible.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The control rod and fuel channel caps,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: which each weigh 350 kilograms,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: are jumping up and down.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: He runs to warn the control room.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But there's nothing he can do to stop what is coming.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: 1:23 and 44 seconds.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The steam blows more fuel channels apart.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We do not know how high the power went.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We only know the final reading.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Reactor 4,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: designed to operate at 3200 megawatts,
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: went beyond 33,000.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The pressure inside the core can no longer be held back.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: At long last, we have arrived. 1:23:45, explosion.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In the instant the lid is thrown off the reactor, oxygen rushes in.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It combines with hydrogen and super-heated graphite.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The chain of disaster is now complete.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Comrade Dyatlov!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Dyatlov!
speaker: LEGASOV

text: No one in the room that night knew
speaker: LEGASOV

text: the shutdown button could act as a detonator.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They didn't know it,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: because it was kept from them.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Comrade Legasov, you're contradicting
speaker: CHARKOV

text: your own testimony in Vienna.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: My testimony in Vienna was a lie.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I lied to the world.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I'm not the only one who kept this secret.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: There are many.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We were following orders,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: from the KGB, from the Central Committee.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And right now, there are 16 reactors in the Soviet Union
speaker: LEGASOV

text: with the same fatal flaw.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: Three of them are still running
speaker: CHARKOV

text: less than 20 kilometers away at Chernobyl.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Professor Legasov, if you mean to suggest the Soviet State
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: is somehow responsible for what happened,
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: then I must warn you, you are treading on dangerous ground.
speaker: JUDGE KADNIKOV

text: I've already trod on dangerous ground.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: We're on dangerous ground right now,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: because of our secrets and our lies.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They're practically what define us.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: When the truth offends, we lie and lie
speaker: LEGASOV

text: until we can no longer remember it is even there.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But it is still there.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Every lie we tell incurs a debt to the truth.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Sooner or later, that debt is paid.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: That is how an RBMK reactor core explodes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Lies.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Valery Alexeyevich Legasov,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: son of Alexei Legasov,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Head of Ideological Compliance, Central Committee.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Do you know what your father did there?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: As a student, you had a leadership position in Komsomol.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Communist Youth, correct?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: you already know. - Answer the D767.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: At the Kuchartov Institute,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: you were the Communist Party secretary.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: In the position, you limited
speaker: CHARKOV

text: the promotion of Jewish scientists.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Yes.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: To curry favor with Kremlin officials.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You're one of us, Legasov.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I can do anything I want with you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: But what I want most is for you to know that I know.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You're not brave.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You're not heroic.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You're just a dying man who forgot himself.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I know who I am, and I know what I've done.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: In a just world, I'd be shot for my lies,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: but not for this, not for the truth.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Scientists...
speaker: CHARKOV

text: and your idiot obsessions with reasons.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: When the bullet hits your skull,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: what will it matter why?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No one's getting shot, Legasov.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: The whole world saw you in Vienna.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It would be embarrassing to kill you now.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And for what?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Your testimony today will not be accepted by the State.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It will not be disseminated in the press.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It never happened.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No, you will live,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: however long you have,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: but not as a scientist, not anymore.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You'll keep your title and your office,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: but no duties, no authority, no friends.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No one will talk to you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: No one will listen to you.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Other men, lesser men,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: will receive credit for the things you have done.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Your legacy is now their legacy.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You'll live long enough to see that.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: What role did Shcherbina play in this?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: None.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: He didn't know what I was gonna say.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What role did Khomyuk play in this?
speaker: CHARKOV

text: None.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: She didn't know either.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: After all you've said and done today,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: it would be curious if you chose this moment to lie.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: I would think a man of your experience
speaker: LEGASOV

text: would know a lie when he hears one.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: You will not meet or communicate
speaker: CHARKOV

text: with either one of them ever again.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You will not communicate with anyone
speaker: CHARKOV

text: about Chernobyl ever again.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: You will remain so immaterial to the world around you
speaker: CHARKOV

text: that when you finally do die,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: it will be exceedingly hard to know that you ever lived at all.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: What if I refuse?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Why worry about something that isn't going to happen?
speaker: LEGASOV

text: "Why worry about something that isn't going to happen?"
speaker: LEGASOV

text: Oh, that's perfect.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: They should put that on our money.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: To be a scientist is to be naive.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: We are so focused on our search for truth,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: we fail to consider how few actually want us to find it.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: But it is always there, whether we see it or not,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: whether we choose to or not.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: The truth doesn't care about our needs or wants.
speaker: LEGASOV

text: It doesn't care about our governments,
speaker: CHARKOV

text: our ideologies, our religions.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: It will lie in wait for all time.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: And this, at last, is the gift of Chernobyl.
speaker: CHARKOV

text: Where I once would fear the cost of truth,
speaker: LEGASOV

text: now I only ask:
speaker: LEGASOV

text: What is the cost of lies?
speaker: LEGASOV
